subsection.title: The Basics

definition.p: A logical proposition is a sentence which is either true of false, but not both.

statement.p: Which of the following are logical propositions?

ol.li: This is a course in discrete mathematics
Wichita is the capitol of Kansas

definition.p: Let p be a logical proposition. The negation of p, denoted by \neg p has the opposite truth value of p.

statement.p: What are the logical negations of each of the following?

definition.p: Let p and q be propositions. The conjunction of p and q, denoted p \wedge q is the proposition p and q . The disjunction of p and q, denoted p \vee q is the proposition p or q (or both).
The logical disjunction is an inclusive or. On the other hand, we define the exclusive or of p and q to be the proposition p or q but not both. We denote the exclusive or (XOR) by p\oplus q.
Let p and q be propositions. The conditional statement is the compound proposition if p then q. The conditional is denoted by p \to q.
We call p the hypothesis or antecedent or premise, and q is the conclusion or consequence.

note.p:
There are many ways to phrase the conditional statement p \to q. Here are just a few common ones:
If p, then q.
p implies q.
p only if q.
p if sufficient for q.
q is necessary for p.
q if p.
q whenever p.
q unless \neg p.

Let p and q be propositions. The biconditional of p and q, is the statement p if and only if q, denoted p \leftrightarrow q.

Other ways to phrase an if and only if statement:
p iff q.
p is necessary and sufficient for q.
If p then q and conversely.

subsection.p:
Just as with arithmetic operations (+, -, \times, \div) on numbers, we need to define an order of operations so that compound propositions can be understood without grouping symbols.
Operator Precedence
\neg highest
\wedge, \vee next, from left to right
\to, \leftrightarrow lowest, left to right
For example:
\neg p \vee q \wedge r \to p \wedge q \\ \equiv \left(\left(\left(\neg p\right)\vee q\right) \wedge r\right) \to \left(p \wedge q \right)
Though for clarity, we will generally write grouping symbols.

subsection.p: Occassionally through this course, we will be working with bit objects. A bit is a number which has values of either 1 or 0. We can operate with bits the same way we operate with propositions: 0 is false and 1 is true. The truth tables for the operations \vee, \wedge, \oplus all apply.
